tossups.question: One side in this battle halted fire due to a miscommunication about the remaining ammunition; to maintain morale, that side informed its men that the pause was to have breakfast. The direction “you may fire when you are ready, Gridley” was given to begin this battle. In this battle, George Dewey’s U.S. fleet lost one sailor to heatstroke and sunk 8 Spanish ships. For ten points, name this May 1, 1898 battle of the Spanish-American War, fought in the harbor of the Philippine capital city.
tossups.answer: Battle of Manila Bay (do not prompt on Manila alone)

tossups.question: An army from this region intercepted King Josiah at Megiddo and killed him. Near the end of his life, the prophet Jeremiah was forced to move to this region against his will. A family fled to this region to escape King Herod’s decree to kill all boys two years or younger. The firstborn of every household in this region was slaughtered before its leader allowed the Israelites to leave. For ten points, name this region that, in numerous Biblical stories, was ruled by pharaohs.

This man sacked the castle of Jacob’s Ford after a bribe of 100,000 gold pieces to stop the castle’s construction was turned down. Though this man was defeated at the Battle of Montgisard, he later formed a truce with Baldwin IV. One campaign against this man was called after his victory at Hattin, though he ended that conflict by granting Christians safe pilgrimage to Jerusalem. For ten points, name this Kurdish founder of the Ayyubid dynasty, an enemy of Richard I in the Third Crusade.
tossups.answer: Saladin (or An-Nasir Salah ad-Din Yusuf ibn Ayyub)

tossups.question: This team lost a group of promising young players in the 1958 Munich air disaster, though a survivor of that crash, Bobby Charlton, held the goalscoring record for this club until 2017. A manager who gave locker room tirades known as “hairdryer treatments” won 13 Premier League titles with this club, which is currently managed by the Portuguese former manager of Chelsea, Jos´e Mourinho. Sir Alex Ferguson once coached, for ten points, what English soccer team led by Zlatan Ibrahimovic and Wayne Rooney?
tossups.answer: Manchester United F.C. (prompt on Manchester and/or United alone; prompt on ManU)

tossups.question: Contemporary historian James Ronda has written several books about this event, one of which claims that a comparable event was led by James Mackay and John Thomas Evans. During this event, Fort Clatsop was constructed along the Columbia River. Participants in this event included a slave named York, Toussaint [too-sahn] Charbonneau, and Charbonneau’s Shoshone wife, Sacagawea. For ten points, name this voyage that explored the Missouri River, including much of the Louisiana Purchase.
tossups.answer: Lewis and Clark Expedition (accept Corps of Discovery)

tossups.question: In ancient times, this currency was worth 6 obols. In 1828, the phoenix replaced the Ottoman kurus, then itself was replaced four years later by the “phoenix,” adorned with King Otto’s face; both this currency and the phoenix were equivalent to 100 lepta. In 1973, this currency replaced the image of the deposed King Constantine with more phoenix imagery and the phrase “Hellenic Republic.” For ten points, name this currency used by both the ancient and modern, pre-Euro Greeks.

This man testified on behalf of Robel Phillipos after the Boston Marathon bombing. In 1988, this man fired Donna Brazile for claiming his opponent was cheating with Jennifer Fitzgerald. During a presidential campaign, this man was attacked for supporting prisoner’s weekend furlough passes in the Willie Horton ad and for opposing “virtually every defense system” in the Tank ad. For ten points, name this former Massachusetts governor who lost to George H.W. Bush in 1988.

This only piece of music this composer wrote for harp was a concerto featuring it with flute. This compoeser’s twenty-fifth piano concerto is nicknamed “Coronation” for its use during the ascension of Leopold II to Holy Roman Emperor. An opera by this composer, whose aria “Der Holle Rache” is known for its coloratura high Fs, had a libretto by Emmanuel Schikaneder that was probably inspired by Freemasonry. The Queen of the Night is found in, for ten points, what composer’s The Magic Flute?

This state’s capital was chosen to be at the site of LeFleur’s Bluff, overlooking the Pearl River. An alluvial plain in this state, home to the towns of Clarksdale and Greenville, is bounded on the east by the Yazoo River and is known for a distinctive variety of blues. Another city here was captured after a 47-day siege by Ulysses S. Grant in 1863. For ten points, a namesake Delta and the city of Vicksburg are located in what Southern state whose capital is Jackson?
For ten points, name this Indian empire ruled by Humayun and Akbar.

One side in this election year used the song “Hunters of Kentucky” to rally support. After suffering a stroke, William Crawford lost support and finished third in this election year. Thanks to the Twelfth Amendment, this election hung on a House of Representatives vote that the loser decried as a “corrupt bargain” struck by Henry Clay. For ten points, name this election year in which John Quincy Adams defeated Andrew Jackson.

David Markson’s best known work is titled for this philosopher’s “Mistress.” Bertrand Russell’s “The Philosophy of Logical Atomism” was based on one of this man’s works. This philosopher once threatened Karl Popper with a hot poker because Popper claimed the existence of moral rules. “The world is everything that is the case” opens a work by this man that he himself later critiqued in his posthumously published Philosophical Investigations. For ten points, name this Austrian philosopher who argued that all philosophical problems were mere “language-games” and wrote Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus.

During this man’s reign, his forces broke a blockade of the Hanko Peninsula in the Battle of Gangut, his country’s first naval victory. A major victory during his reign was the capture of Azov. He reorganized his government with the Table of Ranks and defeated a revolt by the streltsy. He studied shipbuilding in the Netherlands as part of his Great Tour to learn more about Western Europe. For ten points, name this“Great” modernizing tsar of Russia.

In a letter to his cousin Lund, the owner of these objects notes that two of them were“in the secret drawer” of a locker. Jean-Pierre Le Mayeur befriended the owner of these objects in 1781 and helped maintain them. A letter asking for equipment to care for these objects noted there was (+) “little prospect of being in [Philadelphia] soon;” that letter was intercepted by the British and may have convinced Henry Clinton to not reinforce Yorktown. Contrary to (*) legend, wood was not used to fashion a replacement set of these objects, which are now on display at Mount Vernon. For ten points, name these body parts that made public speaking difficult for the first US President.
tossups.answer: George Washington’s (false and/or real) teeth (accept clear equivalents; accept George Washington’s dentures or similar equivalents; do not accept Washington’s wooden teeth, as they weren’t made of wood)

tossups.question: In January 2017, protests erupted against this leader over increases in gas prices known as the “Gasolinazo.” The “I am 132” movement was established to protest this leader’s 2012 election. This leader was heavily criticized for inaction over the 2014 (+) kidnapping of 43 students in Iguala. This man’s namesake “bots” spread propaganda in favor of him and his party, the (*) PRI. This leader canceled a meeting with Donald Trump after he said his country would refuse to pay for a border wall. For ten points, name this current President of Mexico.
tossups.answer: Enrique Pe˜na Nieto (prompt on partial last name)

tossups.question: Athenians who performed a special type of this process were known as cleruchs; the first such example was probably done at Salamis. A brand from an original prytaneum was used in the (+) ceremonial beginning of this process, which started taking place in Ionia, Thrace, and Italy in the 700s BC. (*) Syracuse was created as a result of, for ten points, what general process that spread ancient Greek culture and, more crucially, people, throughout the Mediterranean?
tossups.answer: ancient Greek colonization (accept word forms; accept descriptions of ancient Greeks settling new cities or equivalents; prompt on exploration until “prytaneum” is read)

tossups.question: Honeywell, Inc. v. Sperry Rand Corp overturned a patent created during this project, which was originally called “Project PX.” John Brainerd was the lead investigator during this project, which intrigued John von Neumann enough to lead to its use in (+) H-bomb development at Los Alamos. This project was initially commissioned by the Ballistic Research Laboratory to calculate artillery tables at the University of Pennsylvania, and it became fully operational in 1946. (*) Kay McNulty was one of six women who programmed, for ten points, what “Great Brain” that is often considered the first electronic computer?
tossups.answer: ENIAC (accept Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer)

tossups.question: This man ended a mutiny by declaring to his men “I am waiting for the tanks and the Americans” before launching another attack. After Erich von Falkenhayn declared that he would bleed this man’s troops (+) white in one battle, this man allegedly rallied his men with the cry “they shall not pass.” The “Sacred Way” supply line was established by this (*) marshal, who worked with Pierre Laval in a post-military position that earned him life imprisonment. For ten points, name this war hero at Verdun who collaborated with the Nazis as the head of Vichy France.

The leader of the losing side of this war was killed by a man known as “Frank the Devil.”The Campaign of the Hills was the final phase of this conflict, which included the siege of the Fortress of Humait´a. (+) Rutherford B. Hayes helped lead negotiations in the aftermath of this conflict which included the Battle of Tuyut´ı. Eliza Lynch was the wife of the leader of the losing country, which lost over (*) two-thirds of its adult male population. Francisco Solano L´opez was killed in, for ten points, what war in which Paraguay was defeated by Argentina, Brazil, and Uruguay?
tossups.answer: War of the Triple Alliance (prompt on Paraguay(an) War)

tossups.question: Buffalo Bill rode up to this figure and bowed to her at the Chicago World’s Fair. Ann Gordon argues that pro-life depictions of this figure are an example of “invented memory.” This woman worked with (+) George Train as the publisher of a weekly newspaper called The Revolution; that paper put her ten thousand dollars in debt, according to testimony in which she declared “I shall never (*) pay a dollar of your unjust penalty” after being arrested in Rochester after attempting to vote. For ten points, name this advocate for women’s suffrage who was honored on a 20th century dollar coin.
